name: Abundant Earth
address[a1]: our smallholding can be found near Broompark village at the edge of Durham City, you can see it on google maps but we don't have a postcode or formal address for the site
description: workers coop that manages a smallholding on the edge of Durham City. We grow food, create craft products and run courses in a variety of land based, craft based and people care skills. Our activities include a veg box scheme, willow baskets, yoga courses, non-violent communication courses, creating wood products such as bowls, milling timber, teaching blacksmithing, running permaculture courses and plenty more.
network:
north east permaculture network
transition durham
durham local food network
attendWorkshop: Maybe - it depends what is involved.
suggestedInitiatives: you could send an email to the north east permaculture network

name: ReCoCo
description: Peer-run, Peer-delivered mental health courses, groups and activities. Plus campaigning, particularly on the social injustices that fuel mental distress.
attendWorkshop: Yes - and I have some ideas to share.

name: Station Master's Centre
description:
The Station Master's Centre integrates community, growing, good food, nature, music, art, holistic health, creativity. 
The Station Masters Community Wildlife Garden begins the journey of sourcing for the senses. It provides opportunities and openings for all ages to keep active and connected.
The Yoga Station is about yoga for everybody, but with a difference. We value the evidence of what works, and seek to include those who may need more support to enjoy the benefits of yoga.
The Green Beans Market is a volunteer led enterprise that supports upcycling, thinking, doing - all with a creative focus. It is the only community led market in the region.
The Lamp Light Studio joins together sound and video recording space, with a 'food hub' where we run flavour masterclasses, community food events and help those who have 'altered eating' difficulties when food has lost its joy.
The Station Master's projects are all not for profit. The Centre is supported by Nexus, the Tyne and Wear Transport Authority. And you can reach us by metro!
attendWorkshop: Maybe - it depends what is involved.

name: Scotswood Garden
description: Scotswood Garden is an award winning environmental and community organisation based in the heart of our local neighbourhood which is in the highest 10% for multiple deprivation in the UK. We provide a range of education, support, training, health and wellbeing services from our stunning natural, wild site for people aged 0-90. We use nature based interventions which are proven to improve mental and physical health, strengthen community relationships, and support people to gain new skills, qualifications and experience. We provide a vital and trusted community resource and have grown and developed in response to local need through genuine opportunities for local people to shape our services.
network:
Permaculture Association 
Social Farms and Gardens
Forest School Association 
Community Organisations in Benwell & Scotswood (COBS)
attendWorkshop: Maybe - it depends what is involved.

name: Birkheads Wild CIC
description: We are a social enterprise aimed at helping more young people to discover, explore and enjoy the outdoors. We operate mainly from our 2 acre site in rural Gateshead which is an off -grid, almost- wild campsite (28 day licence), Forest School and a community garden which is in development- currently we have hens and a veg growing area. We run after school and holiday sessions, school and youth club trips and host Duke of Edinburgh’s expeditions.
network:
Informally work collaboratively with Stomping Grounds Forest School. We have also had a student on placement from Gateshead College.
Forest School networks in the NE
attendWorkshop: Maybe - it depends what is involved.

name: We Are Our Media
address[a]: c/o Andrew Wilson, We Are Our Media
description:
We Are Our Media (WAOM) is a self-organised collective of people from across the North East who develop experimental processes to find and present unheard stories in an inclusive and collaborative way.  We are a diverse group in gender, race, class and experience and aim to represent this diversity in all aspects of our activity.

Our Projects include:

The Eclipse - a free-to-access tabloid publication created and distributed by and for its readership. 

Do It Ourselves Journalism – an accessible course introduing the diverse elements of ‘citizen’ or ‘do it ourselves’ journalism. Anchored in a peer-to-peer learning style DIOJ anticipates each participant, regardless of prior experience, can learn from each other. 

Learning & Skill Sharing - one day workshops or events introducing WAOM project and methods to a specific organisation, group or community.
attendWorkshop: Yes - and I have some ideas to share.

name: Newcastle Food Co-op
address[a1]: We are part of the students union but do no have a physical address as such
description:
The Newcastle Food Co-op is a non-hierarchical, not-for-profit, volunteer-run food outlet. It aims to sell ethical foods to the community of Newcastle at affordable prices. It does this by buying food in bulk from food distributers (Currently Suma) and selling it on at cost price.

As well as selling food, the Co-op acts as a social hub where people can come together to discuss healthy eating, and care for the environment, and organize events and action around these issues.

name: CoHUT (Cohousing upon Tyne)
address[a1]: we are working on the feasibility for developing 25 homes on a  brownfield site at this location
description: Cohousing is a type of community in which residents shape and manage their living environment together. As well as individual private dwellings, cohousing communities are built around shared spaces and facilities which encourage neighbourliness and support a high quality of life. Cohousing upon Tyne (CoHUT) is a diverse, multi-generational group of like-minded Tyneside residents with plans to build a cohousing community of 25 affordable, environmentally sustainable homes on Tyneside.  We have a Homes England Community Housing Fund pre-development award to advance feasibility plans on a brownfield site in Scottswood.
network:
We are listed with the UK Cohousing Network https://cohousing.org.uk/
We follow the NE permaculture list and WEA email news bulletins
One member is closely involved with Tyne and Wear Citizens and others volunteer with Star and Shadow
attendWorkshop: Maybe - it depends what is involved.
suggestedInitiatives: I think you have all that we know of

name: The Comfrey Project CIO
description:
A charity funded in 2002, supporting primarily refugees and people seeking asylum to improve their mental health wellbeing and social integration.

We aim to create a safe and welcoming environment for people to heal from trauma and cope with the everyday challenges trying to adapt to a new country and/or grapple with the UK asylum system. Through Social & Therapeutic Horticulture, language support, creative activities, cooking, community events and more, we offer opportunities for productive use of recreational time, socialising, confidence building, skill development and community participation. Moreover, we facilitate opportunities which celebrate diversity and encourage positive interactions between the host and migrant communities. 

We function on principles that encourage ownership and co-production, as well as, the protection of the natural environment with particular focus around food growing and consumption, including food source awareness, grow-your-own and food waste reduction practices and the protection of pollinators.
